trans-unit.source: store-sendgrid-java-how-to-send-email-example
trans-unit.target: store-sendgrid-java-how-to-send-email-example

trans-unit.source: How to send email using SendGrid from Java in an Azure Deployment
trans-unit.target: How to send email using SendGrid from Java in an Azure Deployment

trans-unit.source: How to Send Email Using SendGrid from Java in an Azure Deployment
trans-unit.target: How to Send Email Using SendGrid from Java in an Azure Deployment

trans-unit.source: The following example shows you how you can use SendGrid to send emails from a web page hosted in Azure.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows you how you can use SendGrid to send emails from a web page hosted in Azure.

trans-unit.source: The resulting application will prompt the user for email values, as shown in the following screen shot.
trans-unit.target: The resulting application will prompt the user for email values, as shown in the following screen shot.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Email form</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Email form</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The resulting email will look similar to the following screen shot.
trans-unit.target: The resulting email will look similar to the following screen shot.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Email message</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Email message</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You'll need to do the following to use the code in this topic:
trans-unit.target: You'll need to do the following to use the code in this topic:

trans-unit.source: Obtain the javax.mail JARs, for example from <html></html>.
trans-unit.target: Obtain the javax.mail JARs, for example from <html></html>.

trans-unit.source: Add the JARs to your Java build path.
trans-unit.target: Add the JARs to your Java build path.

trans-unit.source: If you are using Eclipse to create this Java application, you can include the SendGrid libraries in your application deployment file (WAR) using Eclipse's deployment assembly feature.
trans-unit.target: If you are using Eclipse to create this Java application, you can include the SendGrid libraries in your application deployment file (WAR) using Eclipse's deployment assembly feature.

trans-unit.source: If you are not using Eclipse to create this Java application, ensure the libraries are included within the same Azure role as your Java application, and added to the class path of your application.
trans-unit.target: If you are not using Eclipse to create this Java application, ensure the libraries are included within the same Azure role as your Java application, and added to the class path of your application.

trans-unit.source: You must also have your own SendGrid username and password, to be able to send the email.
trans-unit.target: You must also have your own SendGrid username and password, to be able to send the email.

trans-unit.source: To get started with SendGrid, see <link><linkText>How to send email using SendGrid from Java</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To get started with SendGrid, see <link><linkText>How to send email using SendGrid from Java</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Additionally, familiarity with the information at <link><linkText>Creating a Hello World Application for Azure in Eclipse</linkText><title></title></link>, or with other techniques for hosting Java applications in Azure if you are not using Eclipse, is highly recommended.
trans-unit.target: Additionally, familiarity with the information at <link><linkText>Creating a Hello World Application for Azure in Eclipse</linkText><title></title></link>, or with other techniques for hosting Java applications in Azure if you are not using Eclipse, is highly recommended.

trans-unit.source: Create a web form for sending email
trans-unit.target: Create a web form for sending email

trans-unit.source: The following code shows how to create a web form to retrieve user data for sending email.
trans-unit.target: The following code shows how to create a web form to retrieve user data for sending email.

trans-unit.source: For purposes of this content, the JSP file is named emailform.jsp.
trans-unit.target: For purposes of this content, the JSP file is named emailform.jsp.

trans-unit.source: Create the code to send the email
trans-unit.target: Create the code to send the email

trans-unit.source: The following code, which is called when you complete the form in emailform.jsp, creates the email message and sends it.
trans-unit.target: The following code, which is called when you complete the form in emailform.jsp, creates the email message and sends it.

trans-unit.source: For purposes of this content, the JSP file is named sendemail.jsp.
trans-unit.target: For purposes of this content, the JSP file is named sendemail.jsp.

trans-unit.source: In addition to sending the email, emailform.jsp provides a result for the user; an example is the following screen shot:
trans-unit.target: In addition to sending the email, emailform.jsp provides a result for the user; an example is the following screen shot:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Send mail result</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Send mail result</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: Deploy your application to the compute emulator and within a browser run emailform.jsp, enter values in the form, click Send this email, and then see results in sendemail.jsp.
trans-unit.target: Deploy your application to the compute emulator and within a browser run emailform.jsp, enter values in the form, click Send this email, and then see results in sendemail.jsp.

trans-unit.source: This code was provided to show you how to use SendGrid in Java on Azure.
trans-unit.target: This code was provided to show you how to use SendGrid in Java on Azure.

trans-unit.source: Before deploying to Azure in production, you may want to add more error handling or other features.
trans-unit.target: Before deploying to Azure in production, you may want to add more error handling or other features.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: You could use Azure storage blobs or SQL Database to store email addresses and email messages, instead of using a web form.
trans-unit.target: You could use Azure storage blobs or SQL Database to store email addresses and email messages, instead of using a web form.

trans-unit.source: For information about using Azure storage blobs in Java, see <link><linkText>How to Use the Blob Storage Service from Java</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For information about using Azure storage blobs in Java, see <link><linkText>How to Use the Blob Storage Service from Java</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: For information about using SQL Database in Java, see <link><linkText>Using SQL Database in Java</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For information about using SQL Database in Java, see <link><linkText>Using SQL Database in Java</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: You could use RoleEnvironment.getConfigurationSettings to retrieve the SendGrid username and password from your deployment's configuration settings, instead of using the web form to retrieve those values. For information about the RoleEnvironment class, see Using the Azure Service Runtime Library in JSP and the Azure Service Runtime package documentation at .
trans-unit.target: You could use RoleEnvironment.getConfigurationSettings to retrieve the SendGrid username and password from your deployment's configuration settings, instead of using the web form to retrieve those values. For information about the RoleEnvironment class, see Using the Azure Service Runtime Library in JSP and the Azure Service Runtime package documentation at .

trans-unit.source: For more information about using SendGrid in Java, see <link><linkText>How to send email using SendGrid from Java</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about using SendGrid in Java, see <link><linkText>How to send email using SendGrid from Java</linkText><title></title></link>.
